title: Functional Neurological Disorder (FND)
icd10: ** F44.4 (Conversion disorder with motor symptom or deficit)
F44.5 (Conversion disorder with seizures or convulsions)
F44.6 (Conversion disorder with sensory symptom or deficit)

scope: ** Diagnosis (positive clinical signs), acute management, and long-term multidisciplinary treatment of FND. Covers functional motor symptoms (weakness, tremor, dystonia, gait disorder, myoclonus, parkinsonism), functional seizures (PNES/dissociative seizures), functional sensory symptoms, and functional cognitive symptoms. Emphasizes POSITIVE diagnosis based on clinical signs (not diagnosis of exclusion). Includes communication strategies, physical rehabilitation, psychological treatment, and pharmacologic management of comorbidities. For epilepsy, see "New Onset Seizure" and "Status Epilepticus" templates. For organic movement disorders, see specific disorder templates.

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (FND specialist if available) for diagnosis confirmation, positive sign demonstration, and diagnosis delivery
Neuropsychiatry or psychiatry with FND experience for comorbidity management and psychological formulation
Physiotherapy (FND-specialized if available) for movement retraining and functional motor rehabilitation
Clinical psychology (CBT for FND) for illness beliefs, avoidance, and perpetuating factors
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation and graded return to activity
Speech-language pathology if functional voice disorder or functional swallow symptoms
Epilepsy monitoring unit for video-EEG if functional seizures suspected (diagnostic confirmation)
Neuropsychology if functional cognitive symptoms for formal testing and differentiation from neurodegenerative cognitive decline
Pain management if chronic pain comorbidity refractory to standard treatment
Social work for disability support, vocational rehabilitation, and family education
Peer support group for FND (FND Hope, FND Action, local support groups)

Patient Instructions.item: FND is a REAL neurological condition -- your symptoms are genuine and not imagined or fabricated
Visit www.neurosymptoms.org for reliable, expert-written information about FND (recommended by leading FND specialists)
FND is treatable -- many patients improve significantly with the right treatment (physiotherapy, psychology, self-management)
Understanding the diagnosis is the first step in recovery -- ask your neurologist to show you your positive clinical signs
Avoid excessive medical testing and doctor shopping; this can reinforce symptoms and delay recovery
Regular physical activity and graded exercise improve outcomes -- avoid complete rest or bed rest
If you have functional seizures: during an event, try grounding techniques (5 senses exercise); family/friends should NOT restrain you or call 911 unless injury occurs or event lasts >10 minutes
Manage stress, sleep, and general health -- these factors influence symptom severity
Engage with recommended physiotherapy and psychology -- these are the evidence-based treatments
Recovery is often gradual with setbacks -- this is normal and does not mean the diagnosis is wrong
Return to ED for new symptoms that are clearly different from your usual FND symptoms, such as sudden severe headache, fever, or one-sided weakness with facial droop (new stroke symptoms)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Regular aerobic exercise (30 min, 5x/week) to improve mood, reduce pain, and support neuroplasticity
Sleep hygiene: consistent bed/wake times, avoid screens 1 hour before bed, limit caffeine after noon
Stress management: mindfulness, breathing exercises, journaling, or other relaxation techniques
Pacing activities to avoid boom-bust cycle (overactivity on good days â†’ crash on bad days)
Limit alcohol (lowers seizure threshold; interacts with medications; worsens mood/sleep)
Avoid benzodiazepines for functional seizures (ineffective and potentially harmful)
Maintain social connections and meaningful activities -- isolation worsens FND

disposition.criteria: Diagnosis communicated; patient understands FND diagnosis; safety ensured; no acute medical concern; outpatient therapy arranged (PT, psychology); family education completed; resources provided (neurosymptoms.org)

Diagnostic uncertainty requiring further evaluation (video-EEG); severe functional disability preventing safe discharge; acute psychiatric comorbidity (suicidality, psychosis); failure to thrive; recurrent ED visits for functional events requiring care coordination

Generally NOT indicated for FND; consider only if: iatrogenic complications from inappropriate treatment (benzodiazepine-induced respiratory depression); diagnostic uncertainty with concern for status epilepticus
Video-EEG monitoring not available; FND-specialized rehabilitation program referral; neuropsychiatry not available
Severe functional disability; failed outpatient therapy; good engagement and motivation; multidisciplinary program available
ALL patients: neurology follow-up within 2-4 weeks; physiotherapy initiation within 1-2 weeks; psychology referral within 1 month; PCP for comorbidity management
New symptoms DIFFERENT from established FND pattern (evaluate for new neurological disease); acute psychiatric emergency; severe functional deterioration failing outpatient treatment
